p.s: The political speech Remarks of president Barack Obama at student roundtable is a political speech given by the president of the United States of America during a visit in Turkey.

In this speech, which is held to begin an open discussion with the students of the Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University in Tophane in Turkey, the president tries to encourage and inspire the audience to build new bridges instead of building new walls (lines 19-20) through cultural exchanges between the audience and young people from the United States of America.
The speech is given in 4 paragraphs.
In the first paragraph Obama states his reason to give this speech and attend the following roundtable discussion.
The president emphasizes his commitment and envy to rebuild a relationship between the US and the people of the Muslim world, with the adverb deeply (lines 1 and 2).
He continues the speech with further describing the kind of relationship he wants to wiate.
With the repetionrepetition of the word mutual (lines 2 and 3) he loosens the tension of being near a person as important and powerful as him.
This gets supported by the kind of discussion they are having.
A roundtable discussion in which everybody has the same rights and is treated equally.
In the second paragraph Obama shares a trend he has seen in the US of young people, who are deeply engaged into politics, who volunteer abroad or teach at schools.
He then continues with the speech by extending this new surge in activism to other countries.
The president states that everywhere he goes he finds young people who are passionate, engaged and deeply informed about the world around them (cf. lines 7-8).
He uses a climax to emphasize the passion and commitment of these people.
In the third paragraph Obama presents some advantages of cultural exchanges between young people, like the audience.
He thinks that these student exchanges can remind us that we're joined together by our pursuit of a life that's productive and purposeful (cf. lines 14-15).
The president goes on to extend his thesis and says, that through this realization new trust can grow and smaller differences can be out aside.
In the last paragraph Barack Obama appeals to the young students of the Minar Sinan Fine Arts University directly.
He wants them to be progressive, to help building new bridges (l. 19) and end the times of mistrust and hostility.
As the final statement the president of the United States tells the audience that the United States will help them in this mission for peace and trust.

He uses a climax to greatly strengthen the meaning and credibility of his oath to stand by the audience (And I want you to know that in these endeavors, you will find a partner and a supporter and a friend in the United States of America, (ll. 21-22)).
All in all the president gives an inspiring speech to advertise exchanges between young people.
